comments.commentBody:
I would not be surprised to see a younger, more "change" oriented Democrat to get the nomination over a sitting Madame President Clinton if she isn't able to deliver to the liberal base and the Hispanic/Latino electorate after four years in office.

I'm not sure the white electorate embracing Trump are the same as Obama's white voters. But where I live upstate, there are many Trump signs, and knowing these people, they didn't vote for Obama. Trump's anti-government rhetoric is quite different from Obama's who focused on being anti-elite. Trump's stance is very anti-government.

Trump has revealed just how opposed to the big business policies of the GOP the white working class base of the party is. Democrats need to appeal to them. Don't assume they're all racists beyond redemption. In 2020, the Democrats should make an appeal for working class unity against the elites of both parties to win many working class whites back fighting for progressive, up-from-under change.

Can I nominate Elizabeth Warren as 'Bernie plus'? Let her campaign hard against Citizens United and the PACS of both parties, refusing to accept donations above $1K. Strong support for unions and a $15 minimum wage. Penalties for American corporations who send jobs overseas and evade US taxes by skewing their books to reap profits elsewhere.

These are themes that Trump touched on, but he blended them with white nationalist xenophobia. They can be extricated from that reactionary framework and inflected in a positive direction. What the Democrats cannot afford to do is to run a status quo candidate who gives well-paid secret speeches to Goldman Sachs executives and refuses to tell the public what she told them. Never again!
They are equally detested by those in the opposing party.

Haven't read the article yet, but what a terrible, unjust comparison for President Obama.  The other's name does not belong on any line saying they have something in common.  His vile, racist, misogynist self has nothing in common with our respectable, intelligent president.  OK, time to read the article.
The only thing Donald Trump has in common with President Barack Obama is they are both of the male species.

Trees voting for deforestation.

Donald Trump has nothing in common with less-educated and lower-middle class whites, except for the color of his skin. Whereas Hillary has worked hard since she was a child, and certainly wasn't given a million-dollar loan for existing. And she has spent her life fighting to level the playing field for the less fortunate.

It's a sad irony. A Trump presidency will ultimately harm the very blue-collar voters who adore the man. "Don't tread on me," they shout-- but they will be trampled underfoot by an unstable, globalized economy and a weakened democracy.

replies.commentBody: This is a very silly and hysterical argument.  If you lack the intellect to decipher hyperbole and invective, you should retire from political as a commenter.  Trump is not irrational. A big mouth, perhaps.  But he is quite calculated and intelligent despite his bragging.   When Dulles said of the United States that it was prepared to meet any form of Soviet aggression anywhere "at a place of its own choosing" it was immediately understood to be a somewhat cliche and exaggerated claim.  When Trump made his inane comment, it was also understood as an exaggeration. Massive retaliation went the way of MAD and several other nuclear strategies.  Today, we are at a nuclear standstill as most of the world now understands that, similar to MAD, nuclear aggression would mean the death of a huge portion of the world's population.  A rogue state or dictatorship, such as North Korea, is most likely attempt to deploy one of their ICBM (which would possibly be shot down by THAAD).  Trump isn't Truman.  Nice try though.

comments.commentBody:
The US and Russian nuclear arsenals are, essentially, still on hair-trigger alert despite the Cold War having ended over 20 years ago. And the biggest danger in having a belligerent person, like Donald Trump, as Commander-in-Chief of the US Nuclear Arsenal, comes from the potential that such a person would have for unintentionally and accidentally causing the use of nuclear weapons by Russia, against the United States.

I would ask others to take a look at a paper titled ‘Accidental Nuclear War – The Real Danger of a Donald Trump Presidency’ which is posted at www.nucleardanger.org and that discusses this in more detail.
Donald Trump has nothing in common with President Obama. It's insulting to even use their names in the same sentence.
They are both carbon-based life forms?

replies.commentBody: Just some clarification: my grandmother said some people looked like they had swallowed "sour persimmons." Crucial difference.

comments.commentBody: The photographs I've seen of supporters at Trump rallies show the angriest, most dyspeptic groups of people I've ever seen. No smiles, no signs of joy or even relaxation. Even the people sitting behind him during speeches on C-Span look like they've just swallowed persimmons (to quote my late grandma). When I see pictures of the people at Clinton rallies they all look so happy and glad to be there. Just thought I'd throw that in.

Hitler was an extraordinary speaker and had the ability to convince people that he could bring them out of their misery. 1920s was a period of extreme economic hardship for Germany and they could believe anyone who could be that convincing.

I would like to thank the upshot gang for a job well done re the election.

Although when I view their predictions re all other media predictions and think they are a bit biased towards Hillary, nevertheless they made a honest,sincere effort to remain objective.

replies.commentBody: I meant "East Coast + Left i.e. West Coast + Sun Belt".

comments.commentBody:
This is probably the most important insight of this election. Glad that Nat Cohn has been honing this 'Sun Belt versus Rust Belt' argument for a while. While other leading lights of Nat's generation waste their brain power on 'polling' data; it is much more productive that Nat is focusing on 'hard voting' data here.

Interesting question - if Clinton campaign determines by Monday that they have no chance left in PA, MI, WI, OH, NH because loss of this Obama White voters (Iowa is already lost for HRC); will they throw the entire kitchen sink at AZ, TX, CO, VA, GA & NC to stitch an entire electoral victory based on West Coast + Left Coast + Sun Belt?

Or if Clinton is able to hold Upper Blue Wall some how and she brings new bricks in lower / Sun Belt; we are looking at Clinton landslide here?

As most have argued, there are 3 possibilities - narrow win for Trump, narrow win for Clinton or a landslide for Clinton. I guess we wait for some 50 hours or so to know more here...

Mr. Trump is a spoiled rich boy, puerile, vulgar, ostentatious.

Mr. Obama is a gentleman. Except that Mr. Obama was relatively inexperienced when he ran for President, the two men have nothing in common.

replies.commentBody: Why the does the media depict the white working class voter as someone who thinks Obama was a Keynan socialist Muslim?

comments.commentBody:
Obama appealed to the white working class guys because he was somebody they had not seen before ie a black who was running for president as an American and not a black and had some hope for him to reverse the job loses they were going thru.

I think Obama should be given a great deal of credit in many areas but on the specific issue of American blue collar jobs being farmed out to slave labor countries (ie free trade), he did nothing about it..That is why there is the big backlash against both the establishment Republicans and Democrats.

In steps Trump to feed on the remains, the consummate ego maniac demagogue promising these blue collar workers the sky even though Trump was himself implicated in it with big time farming out of jobs in his companies.

Hillary is the sole survivor of the establishment. The only reason she is slightly ahead and not become creamed is because of the Frankenstein Trump that the neo cons (with Democratic help) created.

What Obama shares with Trump is very strict enforcement with existing immigration laws, much to the surprised ignorance of the propagandized, poorly educated Trump Nation voter.

The Obama administration deported more unauthorized immigrants during its first six years than the Republican George W. Bush administration did over its full eight years.

Between 2009 and 2014, 2.4 million people were deported from the U.S., according to a September Pew Research data analysis.

Full data from 2015 and 2016 isn’t available, but if those years keep pace with previous Obama years, about 3.2 million people will have been deported under the Obama administration, a Democratic Administration that Hillary Clinton will likely emulate.

http://www.nydailynews.com/news/politics/obama-deported-record-number-im...

But those poorly educated white voters just can't seem to get enough of that delicious, nutritious Grand Old Propaganda, Prevarication and Poppycock that collapses their IQ while stimulating their fear and loathing.

I'm With Her and her serious, informed public policy.

As a preface, I will admit that I pretty much fit the "coastal elite" demographic, and perhaps that is part of the reason why I have a hard time, intuitively, seeing a large number of people who voted for Obama who now support Trump.  I see too great a difference in the values between the two candidates for such a shift to be significant.  Of course there are going to be some of these (there's some of almost anything), but for me to accept that it is a significant force in the election, I would need to see data.  I don't see convincing data in Cohn's article here: He cites that, among white people without college degrees, "[i]n recent national surveys, Mr. Trump leads Hillary Clinton by 59 percent to 30 percent" while Romney lead Obama by 57 to 35 percent.   Given the imprecision in polling and the greater uncertainty in this election compared to 2012 (including, significantly, much greater third-party participation and more undecided voters), I do not see a convincing case supporting the proposition that a significant  number of Obama supporters have switched to Trump.  It may be true, but it seems to be supposition at this point.  Obviously, once the votes have been cast in this election we'll have a clearer picture.  Right now, though, the data seems inconclusive (at least as it is presented by Cohn), as well as the proposition seeming counter-intuitive (from the perspective of one of those notorious coastal elites).

replies.commentBody: Point of order, more Democrats voted for George Bush than voted for Nader.  Don't blame the Greens for Gore's failure.

comments.commentBody: I agree with the previous comment but I am voting for Hillary. A trump win will be a disaster. However, a Green Party or a Socialist Party fielding its own candidates or supporting Democrats "under certain conditions" for the Senate, Congressional and presidential elections will probably be the best way to prepare for an effective and grassroots third party option. And such preparations should start in 2017. However, we should refrain creating a Ralph Nader result on Tuesday and let Trump win as Ralph Nader supporters paved the way for George Bush in 1999. Wringing hands afterwards won't prevent an unfolding and long lasting disasters.

At the end, Hillary will prevail and she would create history. Despite the sick attempt by Comey, the election will prove that our great nation will survive and continue to grow. Con Don is the embodiment of what's wrong with our Country today. A bully, pathological liar, failed businessman, crook and groper king will be the loser. As cons always do, he perfected the art of manipulation by repeated lying and populist talks. Putin would be dancing on the street if Con Don gets elected. The thug wants to destroy our democracy and destabilize our country. For the same, KGB under his direction helping Wikileak to steal the election for Trump. White anger is understandable. Alas, most of them do not bother to check the facts. The inequality was created by the party which nominated Con Don. Over the years, they survived on a strategy to win elections by serving as puppet of the Wall Street fat cats, race baiting, fear mongering and gerrymandering. They have not pushed a single legislation to help us the people in the last decade. They thrive by fear mongering, division and the art of "gun,god and abortion". They don't care to address the critical structural needs to uplift the people. The resultant toxic effect is the selection of a con man who does not deserve to get elected for any public office in the world. The corrupt partisan Comey supports him to ensure continuation of the looting by the crooks under the direction of the Grand Pathetic Party.

replies.commentBody: I'm not so sure of that. I see highly educated voters forming a centrist party based on common sense. Many highly educated voters recognize that socialism does not work, although portions of it could be used.
As far as economics go we have a two party system in name only. A FDR type of party is way overdue.

Jacqueline,
I too am sorry to hear that your vote will count for Trump. Why not work to change the Democratic Party and hold them accountable instead? Without a true parliamentary style government I'm afraid your dreams of a multi-party government will never happen.

Mark

comments.commentBody: I voted for Obama twice and this time I voted for Jill Stein. The Democrats lost me this year. I think the educated white voter will leave the Democratic party over time, and either the Green Party or a new left party will form. It may take 20 years, but I believe 2016 is the beginning of the end of the two party system.

replies.commentBody:
Imo...excellent posts by Jackie and Frank.....they kinda "get it"...they are not the liberal machine of Hillary, nor the establish dead wing of the republican party nor the demagogue Trump...(although Frank is flirting with it)....

Both posters a welcome relief from the liberal stream on this blog just like I get hope when I see a moderate on a right wing blog...

for working class people???...what about her support of slave labor trade agreements over the past 40 yrs???? Dont get me wrong, I am not for Trump but the neo cons and Hillary helped create the Frankenstein Trump....who seized upon this issue of blue collar jobs being farmed out to slave labor countries that Hillary and all establishment reps. and dems supported...
Well Jeff...an interesting post....but history has shown third parties in this country never survive....more likely a move from right/center right to left/center left by both parties....

comments.commentBody:
I definitely agree with a lot of the analysis of this article. I think the Democrats made a huge mistake by completely ignoring the needs of white working class voters. I am a white educated voter, but my partner is a blue collar white voter. While Hillary occasionally told me I might be able to refinance my $186000 in student loans to try keep me on board, she never made a single attempt to get my partners vote.

Both of us already voted for Jill Stein. I have a feeling the Democrats will become centrist Republicans, and the left-leaning Democrats will either join the Green Party or start a Social Democratic party.

Hillarys coalition is basically held together by Trump being in the race, it will fall apart after she becomes President.
